Alright, now we can use the following commands:
- `mvn clean package` <- Creates the SystemML JAR.
- `mvn clean package -P distribution` <- Creates the SystemML JAR _and_ the various distribution binaries.

This removes the old copyright notices from the license messages. In addition, many files were missing Apache licenses, so they have been added. Additionally, replaced OCO Source Materials notices with Apache licenses where they were found.

Tests completed successfully [here](https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-OnDemand/27/).

@lresende @dusenberrymw One thing I am a bit confused about is that some files (such as AParserWrapper.java) at the end of the GitHub "Files Changed" view show up with "No changes" messages even though it is showing that the files have changed. If you click the View button for the file, you see that the file contains the correct information with the correct license. If I check my local history on my machine, I see that for a file such as AParserWrapper.java, the old license message with the copyright has been replaced with the new license message without the copyright. So I'm not sure why the "No changes" messages appear. Maybe it's an artifact of changing so many files?

An additional point to be aware of is that updating the licenses was more difficult that I originally expected because files in the project have a mix of Unix-style (LF) and Windows-style (CR+LF) linefeeds. The linefeeds in the project should probably be standardized to Unix-style to prevent such difficulties from occurring.
Great, I'll merge this in.  Thanks Glenn!

Thank you for working on this @Wenpei. Your updates look good. However I'm having a little bit of a difficulty. The second commit in the PR contains several updated files but the dml-language-reference.md was not up-to-date before the updates. I would cherrypick the second commit except for the needed dml-language-reference.md which is in the third commit which has 59 files that have already been previously committed. I'm having a little problem doing a diff comparison between my local master and the PR version of dml-language-reference.md (git diff pr-18^..master -- docs/dml-language-reference.md) (Possibly because of the multiple parents of commit 3?).

I hate to ask, but would it be possible to do a new pull request with your updates ((1) delete language reference html file and (2) update other 6 files based off the latest master)?

Also, I noticed you are working on your master branch. Perhaps creating another branch to work on (one branch per pull request) would be a little bit safer and easier than working directly on your master branch? That way you can create a branch based off of the latest code from master, commit your changes to the branch, push the branch to your GitHub, and file a PR for the changes on the branch without affecting your master branch at all. A benefit of this approach would be that you can always pull to your local master from GitHub SystemML and have the latest official code on your master branch. You can then make a branch off of master and commit code, and your commits don't affect your master branch, which is always clean.

Hi Tatsuya

Thanks for the PR. 
1) Agree with your change reg. SPARK_HOME and SYSTEMML_HOME. However, note that SPARK_HOME is not set by default when we install Spark. This is something the user has to do. You can keep that change, but please change DEFAULT_SPARK_HOME to something generic (e.g., _/usr/bin/spark-1.4.0-SNAPSHOT-bin-hadoop2.4_) and put a comment noting that users must override it by pointing to Spark installation on their cluster.

2) Reg. Spark defaults like driver-memory, please keep them for now. This is because the values in spark-defaults.conf affects all users and cluster-wide applications. They can probably go into SystemML-config.xml but let us keep them for now.

3) Please also revert the location of _SystemML-config.xml_ (i.e., remove _conf/_). It is always good to have both _SystemML.jar_ and _SystemML-config.xml_ at the same level. 

Shirish

@deroneriksson, just one minor comment  -- to be precise, you may also want to add JMLC (java api with in-memory data exchange) to supported execution modes.

Hi @nishi-t,

Thank you very much. I have a couple comments from looking at the script.

(1)
I see that the DEFAULT_SYSTEMML_HOME variable is created but isn't used. So probably need to update

```
if [ -z ${SYSTEMML_HOME} ]; then
  SYSTEMML_HOME="."
fi
```

to

```
if [ -z ${SYSTEMML_HOME} ]; then
  SYSTEMML_HOME=${DEFAULT_SYSTEMML_HOME}
fi
```

(2)
At bottom of script, certain variables have ${...} notation such as ${master} but others do not, such as $driver_memory. Do variables such as $driver_memory and $num_executors need to be updated to ${driver_memory} and ${num_executors}?
@shirisht, I will add JMLC to the supported execution modes. Thank you for reviewing.

@deroneriksson, Thanks for the PR. I was just thinking last night that we need to reorganize documentation reg. execution modes. Since you started this thread, can we actually have **Execution Modes** as the main section under **SystemML Documentation**? Let us make that section as the one-stop for all possible ways of running SystemML -- standalone, Hadoop, Spark, JMLC, MLContext, etc. Each of this can be a subsection. We now have this information in various different places. Let us consolidate and make it flow better through this PR. Please feel free if you have any suggestions.

BTW, I think we should also change DML examples in page **DML and PyDML Programming Guide**. For example, we currently show examples that iterate through matrix cells and print them. First, it is not related to ML, and more importantly, it unintentionally advocates bad/less-efficient programming practice of indexing matrices at the cell level. In SystemML, we want to matricize the computations as much as possible. We can however discuss this change as a separate PR. You can create an Documentation issue if the JIRA server is up and running.
@deroneriksson closing this. thank you!

Thanks @deroneriksson  for the detailed documentation. Here are the Initial set of comments. Will provide more as I finish reading the text.
- "We will first run SystemML on a single machine in Hadoop Standalone mode" --> "We will first run SystemML on a single machine with Hadoop running in Standalone mode"
- Please remove IBM internal hostnames such as `bdavm015.svl.ibm.com`. Similarly in command prompts, suh as `[hadoop@bdavm015 ~]$`. 
- Reference to Hadoop and SystemML release tar balls -- are we planning to update them whenever there is a new release (for example, system-ml-0.9..) ?
- Please explain the generated console output -- at least, for the first example.
  - INFO `No default SystemML config file (./SystemML-config.xml) found` (BTW, seems like SystemML-config.xml is not in your working directory)
  - WARN message `hops.OptimizerUtils: Auto-disable multi-threaded text read for 'text' and 'csv' due to thread contention on JRE < 1.8 (java.version=1.7.0_79).`. 
  - Briefly explain `scratch_space/`
After the upgrade, MLBlock cannot be compiled because of changes against Row in Spark. The PR includes the fix for the failure of compiling.
Sorry, I found an issue with this. The generated error message isn't properly displayed. I will investigate. Perhaps I should create a test too to test for an expected error message.

OK, problem exists because I folded ParseException and DMLParseException together but "public ParseException(String message)" and "public DMLParseException(String fname)" are not equivalent. Need to think more about this...

Upon further examination, ParseException is used for purposes besides DML parsing (for example, parsing DMLConfig, merging configs, wrapper for FileNotFoundException and IOException, etc). Some of these should not be converted to DMLParseExceptions because they don't have to do with parsing DML. Perhaps I can remove the Token class but not fold ParseException and DMLParseException together.

Thanks @shirisht for your feedback. I will make those updates.

With regards to the tar ball version number question, that is a very good point to bring up. Version numbers can be extracted to a yml file for the documentation so that the version can be stored in a single place and it can be referenced from multiple locations. Ideally it would be nice if that version number in the yml file could be automatically generated based on the version number in the pom. Maven resource filtering might allow that to work. It would also be nice if the particular yml file/value being updated was gitignored so that it didn't need to be committed. I will think about this to see if I can come up with a clean solution.
@deroneriksson I still believe it would be useful to merge these exceptions. The instances of ParseException that are not related to parsing could be replaced with LanguageException.

@asurve , it is impossible to put these intermediates during parfor optimization into the symbol table
because they might be created multiple times in deep control structures. Please, try to add the related code to VariableCPInstruction.processInstruction (createvar). If the newly created matrix object is marked as update in-place, then allocate the matrix block similar to DataConverter.createDeepCopyExecutionContext. The parfor optimizer should only mark the hop for update in-place, the flag is then compiled into the instruction and during runtime you can create the special matrix object during createvar instructions. Note that you need to update Hop.clone() too, otherwise the update in-place flag is lost on deep copy of HOP DAGs during dynamic recompile. For debugging your change, please, double check that your update-in place flag is still existing on processing the related createvar instruction. Thanks.

@shirisht 

> I actually like your previous change where you build full Spark configuration parameters in the while loop. 

OK. I reverted to it and tested the script with various combinations of possible aruguments in the commit 4a4426bf311eed273db6a52dbf44f2c3d4d6c7c5
As a result of this change, I had to change the description of setting default parameters in the script.

For example, default spark parameters is defined by following way in my latest commit:

``` sh
master="--master yarn-client"
driver_memory="--driver-memory 20G"
```

Instead of (previous commit)

``` sh
master=yarn-client
driver_memory=20G
```

This change make setting default parameters somewhat redundant, but I choose this simplest way for now.
Please review again.

That is correct @Wenpei. It should be **index.return**
